org.gearvrf.periodic

Class GVRPeriodicEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.periodic.GVRPeriodicEngine

  • public class GVRPeriodicEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    Schedule runnables to run on the GL thread at a future time. You can schedule one-shot events and you can schedule periodic events, which will either run forever, or run for a fixed number of times, or until your callback tells them to stop.

    The periodic engine is an optional component of GVRF: You need to get the singleton in order to use it. For example, 

     
 Runnable pulse = new Runnable() {
 
     public void run() {
         new GVRScaleAnimation(uiObject, 0.5f, 2f) //
                 .setRepeatMode(GVRRepeatMode.PINGPONG) //
                 .start(mAnimationEngine);
     }
 };
 gvrContext.getPeriodicEngine().runEvery(pulse, 1f, 2f, 10);
    will grow and shrink the uiObject ten times, every other second, starting in a second. This can be a good way to draw the user's attention to something like a notification.

    The engine maintains a priority queue of events, which it checks in a frame listener; events run as run-once events. Every frame, GVRF runs any run-once events; then any frame listeners (including animations); then your method; and then it renders the scene. This means that any periodic events that run on a given frame will run before any animations. It also means that there is always a one frame delay between the time an event is dequeued and the time it actually runs. Scheduling an event from a point in the render pipeline after the periodic engine will add an additional one frame delay. (The periodic engine may run before the animation engine or after it - try not to write code that depends on one running before the other.) Running at 60 fps, each frame is normally 17 milliseconds apart, unless you add too many callbacks or put too much code into your onStep(); Android garbage collection can introduce additional delays.

                                                float delay)
        Run a task once, after a delay.
        Parameters:
        task - Task to run.
        delay - Unit is seconds.
        Returns:
        An interface that lets you query the status; cancel; or reschedule the event.

      • runEvery

        public GVRPeriodicEngine.PeriodicEvent runEvery(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                                float delay,
                                                float period)
        Run a task periodically and indefinitely.
        Parameters:
        task - Task to run.
        delay - The first execution will happen in delay seconds.
        period - Subsequent executions will happen every period seconds after the first.
        Returns:
        An interface that lets you query the status; cancel; or reschedule the event.

      • runEvery

        public GVRPeriodicEngine.PeriodicEvent runEvery(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                                float delay,
                                                float period,
                                                int repetitions)
        Run a task periodically, for a set number of times.
        Parameters:
        task - Task to run.
        delay - The first execution will happen in delay seconds.
        period - Subsequent executions will happen every period seconds after the first.
        repetitions - Repeat count
        Returns:
        null if repetitions < 1; otherwise, an interface that lets you query the status; cancel; or reschedule the event.

      • runEvery

        public GVRPeriodicEngine.PeriodicEvent runEvery(java.lang.Runnable task,
                                                float delay,
                                                float period,
                                                GVRPeriodicEngine.KeepRunning callback)
        Run a task periodically, with a callback.
        Parameters:
        task - Task to run.
        delay - The first execution will happen in delay seconds.
        period - Subsequent executions will happen every period seconds after the first.
        callback - Callback that lets you cancel the task. null means run indefinitely.
        Returns:
        An interface that lets you query the status; cancel; or reschedule the event.
